div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Reporter, [1910?]
div1.p:
Only 10 years ago another young
man made a discovery which The Re-
porter believes was a more notable
achievement than the discovery of the
North Pole. For centuries men had
been dying by the thousands in trop-
ical countries from the yellow fever.
The theory that the disease was
transmitted by mosquitoes was ad-
vanced by scientists.

While the American army was in
Cuba and after thousands of patriotic
young men had died in their country's
service Dr. Jesse Lazear, descendant
of an old Greene county family, and
educated at Trinity Hall in this town,
volunteered to allow physicians to ex-
periment as to the correctness of this
theory upon him.

He was bitten by a mosquito which
was innoculated with yellow fever,
took the dread disease and died in a
few days. His heroic sacrifice demon-
strated the correctness of the theory
and enabled the army surgeons to
save the lives of thousands of his
countrymen.

The noble exploit of Dr. Lazear did
not receive one-thousandth part of the
encomium which has been heaped
upon Dr. Cook. And yet for all prac-
tical purposes and so far as the good
of mankind is concerned was it not
by far the greater achievement?
Lazear's sacrifice has enabled Uncle
Sam to dig the Panama Canal without
the loss of life from the dreaded yel-
low fever.

In all tropical countries the world
over the value of Dr. Lazear's service
to mankind is appreciated and held in
grateful remembrance. But the loud
acclaim which has greeted the an-
nouncement of what Dr. Cook did was
absent a decade ago when the active
agent in the transmission of yellow
fever was located.

Dr. Lazear did not live to see the
benefit which his heroic immolation
proved to be to the race. Dr. Cook
comes back covered with glory and is
welcomed by the plaudits of the
world. Which achievement confered
the greatest benefit upon mankind?
